meanings.definition: To place before or in front of
meanings.sent1: I will prepose the snacks on the table before the guests arrive.
meanings.sent2: She likes to prepose the important documents on her desk for easy access.
meanings.sent3: Before the meeting, he decided to prepose the idea of a team outing.
meanings.sent4: The artist preposed the vibrant colors in the foreground of the painting.
meanings.sent5: To make a statement, prepose your argument clearly and confidently.

meanings.sent1: Let me prepose the topic of our next discussion during this meeting.
meanings.sent2: The teacher always preposes interesting questions to spark class discussions.
meanings.sent3: Before the trip, she jokingly preposed the idea of bringing a pet parrot.
meanings.sent4: The author preposed a twist in the plot that surprised the readers.
meanings.sent5: To avoid confusion, prepose your questions at the beginning of the presentation.

meanings.definition: To offer as an initial proposal
meanings.sent1: I will prepose a budget plan for the project at the next meeting.
meanings.sent2: He decided to prepose a new strategy to improve sales in the company.
meanings.sent3: Before the negotiation, she preposed a creative solution to the problem.
meanings.sent4: The team preposed a unique concept that caught the client's attention.
meanings.sent5: To start the discussion, prepose your ideas for consideration.
